title: Tuesday, 22nd August, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:01am

So yesterday we were complaining about not having any news

PM11:01am

And today we

11:01 am
PM11:01am

have too much

PM11:02am

And I'm all over the shop

PM11:02am

And the network here seems to be on some go slow

11:02 am
PM11:02am

And it's all putting me in a very bad mood

PM11:02am

Best get a pic up

PM11:02am

Only one chap to feature this morning

11:02 am
PM11:03am

PM11:03am

Peter Crook

PM11:03am

He really is crook.

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Not crooked

PM11:03am

Just crook

PM11:04am

When was the last time we saw a Footsie stock fall 67 per cent!?!!??!

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Of course this very clearly began to leak properly last friday

PM11:04am

Bryce is having system problems

PM11:04am

So let's quote him from the back end of last week

11:04 am
PM11:05am

The rather longer answer is that, if Provident were to put out a second profit warning due to the insourcing of its collection agent network, no one would be particularly surprised.

PM11:05am

You'll remember its first profit warning was based on the idea that the collection agents would be back up to speed pretty much instantly.
11:19 am
BE
Which looked ambitious, given the difficulty of winning back door-to-door credit customers if you stop visiting them for a few weeks.
BE
Question two mostly relates to how bad trading has to get before the dividend is toast.

PM11:05am

Well -- we sure got an answer to that question this morning

11:05 am
PM11:06am

Not only is the final toast -- the interim already announced is also cancelled.

PM11:06am

ScorchedfingersTinhatScorchedfingersTinhat

PM11:06am

What was this stock a couple of months back?

11:06 am
PM11:06am

30 quid??

BE11:06am

Yeah, something like that.

BE11:06am

Well okay .... we did write about the very high chances of a Provident Financial profit warning on the 15th August, the 18th August, the 21st August, and if we want to go historic, on July 3rd as well.

11:06 am
BE11:07am

It's fair to say folk saw this coming.

PM11:07am

BE11:08am

Except Woodford! Who seems to have looked at the evidence that Provident was being wildly optimistic on an instant recovery of collection rates and sold .............. Glaxo!

11:08 am
PM11:08am

Woodford must be having his worst year ever

BE11:09am

Provident's a top-five holding of his, yes. Then there's Circassia. And something called Allied Minds, which might be familiar to our regular readers.

PM11:09am

Embarassed smile

11:09 am
BE11:10am

And AstraZeneca, of course, whose cancer thing doesnae work.

BE11:10am

(Scientific term.)

BE11:10am

Anyway, heading back into Provident .............

11:10 am
BE11:11am

It's the bit we were expecting, as in agent collections are disastrous post the insourcing of the sales force.

BE11:11am

But also, there's sub-prime PPI in there.

PM11:11am

Repayment Option Plan thing

11:11 am
PM11:11am

Neil was onto this six years ago!

PM11:11am

https://ftalphavil...nk-and-an-apology/

PM11:12am

This swing on the agent collections is crazy -- £80m divisional profit now looking like a loss of £100m

11:12 am
PM11:12am

How did they manage that?

BE11:13am

Yep. Citi, I think, was talking last week about dividend support even if the home credit business disappears entirely. Turns out that was optimistic! It's now heavily lossmaking!

BE11:13am

The're losing money from loan sharking! It's quite something!

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Let me get some new forecasts.

BE11:14am

JP Morgan Caz.

BE11:14am

Disruption to Home Credit. Following the announcement on 20 June 17, Provident has released another statement relating to the disruption of the Home Credit business. The main objectives for Q317 were to integrate the new operating model (effective since 6 July 17) and restore customer service and collections to levels that would support the division ahead of the busy Q417 trading period. Progress, however, has been weaker than expected with collections performance running at 57% vs. 90% in 2016 and sales at £9m per week lower than 2016. As a result, management are guiding towards a pre-exceptional loss in the business of £80m-120m vs. previous +£60m guidance.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

Actually, no figures in this. Most brokers seem to have gone for "under review" .............. I'll continue anyway as it's a handy recap.

BE11:15am

FCA investigation into Vanquis Repayment Option Plan (ROP). While the company cites that the trading performance of Vanquis, Moneybarn and Satsuma remain in line with expectation, we note the FCA is currently investigating the Vanquis ROP product which contributes gross revenues of £70m pa. Vanquis has agreed to pay no dividends pending the outcome of this investigation.

 Dividend and capital. The deterioration in Home Credit combined with the uncertainty around the FCA's investigation into Vanquis has forced the Board to withdraw the interim dividend in order to preserve group capital. The full-year dividend (JPMe 135p) is now unlikely.

PM11:15am

The full-year dividend (JPMe 135p) is now unlikely???

11:15 am
PM11:15am

Er

BE11:16am

Well, they're not wrong. It is quite unlikely.

PM11:16am

Maybe Caz should revisit the statement

11:16 am
PM11:16am

They've recalled cheques for the interim!

BE11:16am

Let me get something more substantive.

BE11:17am

Here's RBC's Peter Lenardos, fresh off a quite brutal conference call.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

The Executive Chairman (previously: Non-Executive Chairman) will stay as long as required to stabilise the business. The CEO (Peter Crook) has left the business with immediate effect.
l
The FCA investigation into Vanquis Bank: today was the first day that the company disclosed this to the market, despite the company knowing about it for some time. The company did this in order to put the withdrawal of the dividend and the likelihood of no final dividend “in context” with the issues PFG is experiencing in its consumer credit division. Given that the FCA investigation has the potential to be material to the company, investors are likely to take the view that this investigation should have been disclosed when it was known.
l
Provident Financial is “perfectly comfortable” that the dividend cancellation for all of 2017 (both the interim and the final) should prevent an equity capital raise. While comforting, the company did not rule out an equity raise. Further, Provident Financial has nearly £150MM of goodwill and intangibles on its balance sheet, some of which are likely impaired given current trading conditions.
l
The company is not putting a timeline on the return to profitability in the Consumer Credit Division (which made £115.2MM in 2016A and will lose between £80MM and £120MM in 2017E).
l
Provident Financial’s financial covenants allow maximum gearing of up to 5.0x (H1/17: 2.3x). Provident also has a net worth covenant of at least £400MM. It is our understanding that PFG’s pension asset (which is £85MM as of 30 June 2017) is excluded from these covenants l
Provident has a retail bond of £120MM that matures in October 2017. PFG believes that it has funding (through committed facilities plus Vanquis Bank retail deposits) to provide funding through to the seasonable peak in 2018.

Adjusting our forecasts just for the new CCD guidance would cause at least a 55% reduction in our 2017E PBT forecast (at the midpoint of the loss range) – assuming all else equal. Provident Financial’s book value – which excludes the pension asset and as of 30 June 2017, is 446p per share. Our conclusion from this morning still stands: the shares are not investable until greater clarity is received, which may not be until next year at the earliest.

BE11:18am

And Peel Hunt, also off the call.

BE11:19am

Actually, the note pre call was more readable. Let me quote that one instead.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Home credit: The best thing that Provident could do is roll back the clock and return to a model of self-employed agents, although they remain committed to the current model for the time being. Home credit is a community based lending product where the relationship between the collection agent and the borrower is sacrosanct. Technology can be used to great effect to make these businesses more efficient and secure but efficacy of collections is still based on the agent borrower relationship. At the time of the 20th June profits warning Provi’s indicated that pre-exceptional profit would reduce to c£60m. At this time, management hoped that Q3 would see an customer service levels restored and collections returned to acceptable levels (12% of agencies were vacant and collections were behind to the tune of £40m). The rate of progress seen to-date has been below management expectations “too weak” with collections performance running at 57% versus 90% in 2016 and sales £9m lower than the comparative period in 2016. The business is now expected to make a loss of £80m-£120m

BE11:19am

Vanquis & Dividends to Group: To add to Provi’s woes FCA has launched an investigation into repayment option plans (ROP) sold within Vanquis. ROP’s are Provi’s answer to Payment Protection Insurance and contribute gross revenues of £70m per annum – not an inconsiderable sum given what’s likely to be a high drop through rate. FCA is investigating the period from 1st April 2014 to 19th April 2016. Sales of ROP have been suspended since April 2016. It has also been agreed with PRA that the bank will not pay dividends up to the group, without PRA permission. Bank regulation is focused on the protection of depositors and given the deterioration in trading performance and the potential for elevated deposit outflows you can understand why PRA is keen to ensure that the bank remains well capitalised. Fortunately, the majority of deposits are in term accounts that may help to prevent a significant near term outflow although even term accounts can be withdrawn with the loss of interest.

Other businesses: Trading performance of the other businesses including Vanquis, Moneybarn and Satsuma remain in line with internal plans, but as I’ve commented on multiple occasions in the past I have longer term concerns over the greater economic sensitivity to which these business expose to the Group.

My thoughts: Today is going to be painful with the dividend gone and trading performance of the Home Credit business falling off a cliff and showing no signs of improvement. Regardless of the government deposit guarantee there is a tail risk in terms of retail deposit funding and this will need to be monitored carefully over the next few weeks/months. Will middle class Daily Mail readers take fright and move their money? To some extent the fact that Vanquis holds term deposits may help, but renewal rates are likely to suffer and the cost of deposits is likely to rise.

PM11:20am

Okay, this looks like further deterioration from here, culminating in a rescue rights early next year

11:20 am

BE11:21am

.....Which they might've, but there's not that big a short out there.

11:22 am

As we noted in the paper this very morning, short went from 5% of float at the warning to 7.7% at the second, which is not that much really.

BE11:23am

Lansdowne Partners, AQR and Systemica Investments all have +0.5% shorts there. But at least in terms of disclosures, it's not been a feast. Which is surprising, given how damn obvious this warning was.

PM11:23am

Btw -- why is the FCA only now looking at Vanquis Bank??

11:23 am

PM11:24am

11:24 am

Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 183.00, up 6.05 (+3.42%), High: 183.85, Low: 176.95, Volume: 13.17m
11:31 am
BE11:31am

(@alewis2005: no. Though it was always amusing to see Next fall after each profit warning from NXT, the aim-listed speaker manufacturer with a very similar ticker.)

BE11:31am

So ..............

BE11:31am

Goldman:

11:31 am
BE11:31am

In the four weeks to August 13, 2017 grocery market growth slowed to +2.5% vs +4.8% in the prior period and above the +0.7% growth seen in 2016, which we believe reflects the poorer weather conditions in the UK over this period.

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

BE11:32am

(@chopper: yesterday, bud.)

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Aldi and Lidl took 150 bp market share vs. 153 bp in the previous four weeks and 105 bp in 2016; this is their seventh consecutive combined monthly market share gain of greater than 120 bp. Combined market share reached an all-time high of 12.4%.

BE11:32am

Tesco: +2.6% from +4.3% in the prior period. Sainsbury: -0.6% vs. +3.6%. Morrisons: +2.6% vs. +2.1%.

BE11:33am

What’s interesting
As expected, with the good weather period ending in the UK, we saw market growth come back to +2.5% (+4.8% last period). With continued inflation, this implies Big 4 volume were negative. This is coincident with Aldi and Lidl continuing their share gains (+150 bp this period), with an average of +140 bp YTD, tracking well ahead of 2016 gains (105 bp). In the context of last week’s CPI-PPI release for July continuing to track very negatively (-2.9%), this points to a structurally pressured industry whereby inflationary pressures are not being fully passed onto the consumer.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

We also note Morrisons losing no market share this period, its best since December 2016 (+11 bp). This is supported by its strong growth in Food and Drink sales of +2.8% (in the 4-week period). Tesco also saw solid food and drink sales growth of +2.5%, which contrasts with Sainsbury, which saw -0.5% declines, indicating very negative volumes in the category. Also of interest is M&S, which had seen three months of market share losses; this period saw grocery sales growth of +5.6% (+2.4% last period) and market share gains of 7 bp (-9 bp).

BE11:34am

Jefferies also, since we're here.

BE11:34am

Bottom line the industry appears to have returned to negative volumes after misleadingly encouraging levels of activity back in June and most of July. Interestingly, card data suggests that out-of-home meal expenditure continues to grow strongly (and we struggle to accept that increased foreign tourist visits can fully explain this).

...surprisingly discounters are also slowing with the two German players seeing sales growth of 16.7% against 18.5% in the previous 3MMA. At the other end of the spectrum, M&S food looks impressive with gains of 5.7% reassuring after less than 3% in the previous 3MMA. Waitrose remains challenged at 1.2%, confirming that M&S is winning at the higher end of the market. The mid-market segment has slowed given growth of 1.3% at the UK majors, after closer to 3% in the previous 8 weeks.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Tesco strong despite a very tough comp... as we have started cycling the big pick up in sales of H2 2016 at the UK market leader (a pick up that persisted through to November last year). So while the +1.9% increase in cash sales reported today is clearly slower than the previous 3.6%, it was achieved against a 270bps toughening comp. Gains in food sales remain the key driver, at +2% over the most recent 4-week period.

...while Sainsbury weakened sharply as cash sales of -0.2% were clearly weaker than the previous 4%. A 320bps tougher base was a factor behind this dynamic, but the business now seems to be trading at clearly -ve LFLs, with grocery sales even more pressured at -1.3%. Tesco's resurgence seems to be having an impact on JS.

Morrisons remains good... with cash sales growth of 2.5% confirming a slight pick up on the previous 2% (albeit helped by a 160bps easier base of comparison). MRW's ability to withstand a better performing ASDA is encouraging, and we believe consistent with our estimate for Q2 retail LFL of slightly below 2%.

...despite a more resilient ASDA which last week reported CSS of +1.8% for Q2 (note this covered the calendar quarter and was flattered by the timing of Easter; we expect the underlying LFL ex-calendar to have been slightly positive). Kantar today details ASDA cash sales of 0.8%, confirming the narrower rate of underperformance enjoyed by WMT's UK subsidiary since February/March this year.

PM11:35am

So depressing, everyone shopping at discount grocers, even if growth is slowing

BE11:35am

I'll note again the disconnect between Aldi and Lidl growing like the clappers and French's mustard being valued at $4.2bn.

11:35 am

Antofagasta PLC (ANTO:LSE): Last: 981.00, up 26.5 (+2.78%), High: 1,007, Low: 960.00, Volume: 1.15m
BE11:39am

(@BT: I think all that means is that, if the agent stops visiting every week, they'll tend to lose the borrower to someone who does. You can call that a relationship, or you can use other words that would get me into trouble.)

11:39 am
BE11:40am

It's a small beat against consensus, and of course the sector has already had a hell of a rally on China choking off supply.

BE11:40am

Morgan Stanley can summarise.

BE11:40am

Antofagasta reported a group EBITDA (including its share of Zaldivar) of US$1.08bn, 1% and 3% ahead of our and consensus estimates, respectively. Lower taxes (~US$30mn) and minority interests (~US$16mn) widened the beat at the Net Income level to 17% (6% vs consensus). Consequently, the company's 'formulaic' dividend came in 17% ahead of our forecast at USc10.3/share and remaining within the company policy of a minimum payout of 35%.

11:40 am
BE11:41am

FCFE fared better than our estimates, coming in at ~US$460mn (MSe US$78mn). This can be attributed to (1) approximately US$140mn in working capital release (MSe US-$50mn), (2) US$100mn lower tax payments vs our estimates, and (3) US$50mn lower dividends paid to minorities. Consequently, net debt fell to US$860mn as compared to our estimate of ~US$1,150mn. This results in net debt/(annualised 1H EBITDA) for the period at less than 0.5x.

BE11:41am

No changes to guidance, tax rate at lower end of range. Unsurprisingly, the company is guiding for a tax rate closer to the lower end of their guidance of 35-40% given the improved margins (i.e. non-tax deductible items lower as a percentage of absolute profits) and the positive price developments. We currently forecast an effective tax rate of 38%.

BE11:41am

Stretched valuation, rising capital intensity keep us Underweight. In spite of the strong performance at Centinela, we caution that grades will continue to decline (and remain volatile). This, in addition to rising rock hardness at Los Pelambres, would lead to rising costs. We worry that Antofagasta will execute on its extensive growth pipeline, thus draining excess cash flows through 2020 (2017-2020 FCF yield at -5%+4% on spot). We estimate the shares are pricing in a copper price of US$3.0-3.1/lb, thus offering a narrow safety margin.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Always expensive, is 'fags. And the reasons for it being expensive -- low debt, exceptionally cheap tonnage, stable single-country low-political-risk ops, etc -- have gradually been disappearing.

11:51 am
PM11:52am

BE11:52am

True. And on that theme .... @Forester: haven't heard anything new on AA. The equity is a stub to the debt though, so volatility isn't remarkable in itself.

BE11:52am

Also, several requests for BHP ...............

11:53 am
BE11:53am

(@Lefevre: space needs to be filled between the adverts. It's the curse of physical media.)

BE11:53am

BHP numbers in line, net debt a bit better ........

BE11:54am

US shale classified as non-core, interestingly.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Which might appease Elliot, or might just encourage them.

BE11:54am

Divi's a tad light against consensus but not worryingly so.

BE11:54am

Here's Barclays.

11:54 am
BE11:55am

BHP Billiton has reported a decent set of FY17 results. EBITDA beat our estimate and consensus by 1-2%, cash flows were much stronger than expected, leaving net debt down to $16.3bn vs our expectation of $19.4bn and consensus of $18bn. Underlying earnings were slightly weaker than expected (-2% vs our est and -5% vs consensus) due to higher finance charges. Likewise, cost-cutting performance slowed materially in H2-17 to $0.1bn as a result of volumes at the lower end of guidance and increased exploration taking the FY17 figure to $1.3bn vs a target of $1.8bn, representing 7% of COGS. A further $2bn is targeted over the next two years. The proposed final dividend of 43c/sh was slightly below our expectations (-7%) and consensus (-1%), driven by a payout ratio of 66% vs. 50% minimum target, reflecting difference between net income ($6.7bn) vs. FCF ($12.6bn) resulting from the currently low capex/D&A ratio of 0.7x. This takes the total dividend to 83c/sh, implying a 4.7% yield and a 66% payout. FY17 capex and exploration of $5.2bn compares to guidance of $5.6bn while guidance for FY18 was increased to $6.9bn with management leaving themselves room to increase capex further pending approval of growth projects (guidance of below $8bn in both 2018 and 2019). BHP provided an absolute net debt target range of $10-15bn for the first time. On spot, we estimate net debt to fall to $13bn in FY18 but only in that range in FY19 on our base case.

The decision to sell the US onshore business and delay of approval for the Jansen project will likely be taken as a positive by the market. We value the shale assets at c.$5bn vs book value of $11bn and consensus as per Elliott’s April presentation of $6.5bn (range of $4.1-12bn). A sale at book value would imply an uplift of only 6% of market cap vs our expectations assisted by a likely re-rating of the shares given improved ROCE.

BE11:55am

BHP should be a straightforward investment case with high margins from tier 1 assets delivering strong cash flow that management turns into growth and dividends. Right now, however, many issues cloud the investment case including higher relative debt and capital allocation. That said, the decision today to sell the shale assets and delay approvals in Jansen should be welcomed by the market. We believe Elliott's arrival on the register plus new chairman can only prove positive for the medium-term investment case as a result of greater urgency and focus on strategy (vide Unilever). Ultimately though, it is difficult to foresee meaningful outperformance unless the oil price rises significantly. As such, the company’s premium valuation on PER (7.6x spot 2018 vs. RIO 6.6x) and EV/EBITDA (4.3x vs. RIO 3.8x) seems difficult to justify vs RIO particularly given BHP’s bias to still focus on debt reduction given its higher leverage, hence our EW.

BE11:56am

And ..... I dunno, Citi?

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Implications — We expect no significant impact on consensus estimates following today’s result as guidance was on expected lines. The decision to exit US Onshore will generally be viewed positively, although it looks like shareholders will have to wait a while longer before capital management, ex dividends, kicks off in earnest.

BE11:58am

We spent about three years talking about whether BHP should press on with the Jansen project then sort-of forgot it existed.

BE11:58am

Was genuinely surprised this morning to be reminded of it.
